speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: SCENE II. The palace.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter the DUCHESS OF YORK, with the two children of CLARENCE

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: No, boy.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Why do you look on us, and shake your head,

speaker: Girl
text_entry: And call us wretches, orphans, castaways

speaker: Girl
text_entry: If that our noble father be alive?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: My pretty cousins, you mistake me much;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I do lament the sickness of the king.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: As loath to lose him, not your father's death;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Then, grandam, you conclude that he is dead.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: The king my uncle is to blame for this:

speaker: Boy
text_entry: God will revenge it; whom I will importune

speaker: Boy
text_entry: With daily prayers all to that effect.

speaker: Girl
text_entry: And so will I.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Peace, children, peace! the king doth love you well:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Incapable and shallow innocents,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: You cannot guess who caused your father's death.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Grandam, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Told me, the king, provoked by the queen,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Devised impeachments to imprison him :

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And when my uncle told me so, he wept,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And hugg'd me in his arm, and kindly kiss'd my cheek;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Bade me rely on him as on my father,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And he would love me dearly as his child.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He is my son; yea, and therein my shame;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ay, boy.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I cannot think it. Hark! what noise is this?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, with her hair about her ears; RIVERS, and DORSET after her

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To chide my fortune, and torment myself?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I'll join with black despair against my soul,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And to myself become an enemy.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What means this scene of rude impatience?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To make an act of tragic violence:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If you will live, lament; if die, be brief,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Or, like obedient subjects, follow him

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: As I had title in thy noble husband!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I have bewept a worthy husband's death,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And lived by looking on his images:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And I for comfort have but one false glass,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Which grieves me when I see my shame in him.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And hast the comfort of thy children left thee:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Edward and Clarence. O, what cause have I,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thine being but a moiety of my grief,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd;

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Give me no help in lamentation;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I am not barren to bring forth complaints

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That I, being govern'd by the watery moon,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

speaker: Children
text_entry: Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.

speaker: Children
text_entry: What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What stays had I but they? and they are gone.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Was never widow had so dear a loss!

speaker: Children
text_entry: Were never orphans had so dear a loss!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Was never mother had so dear a loss!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas, I am the mother of these moans!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I for an Edward weep, so do not they:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Pour all your tears! I am your sorrow's nurse,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And I will pamper it with lamentations.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: That you take with unthankfulness, his doing:

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful,

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: With dull unwilligness to repay a debt

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Of the young prince your son: send straight for him

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, and RATCLIFF

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, have comfort: all of us have cause

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To wail the dimming of our shining star;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But none can cure their harms by wailing them.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I did not see your grace: humbly on my knee

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I crave your blessing.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Amen; and make me die a good old man!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That is the butt-end of a mother's blessing:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I marvel why her grace did leave it out.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That bear this mutual heavy load of moan,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now cheer each other in each other's love

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Though we have spent our harvest of this king,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We are to reap the harvest of his son.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Me seemeth good, that, with some little train,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which would be so much the more dangerous

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Where every horse bears his commanding rein,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And may direct his course as please himself,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I hope the king made peace with all of us

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And the compact is firm and true in me.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And so in me; and so, I think, in all:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Yet, since it is but green, it should be put

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To no apparent likelihood of breach,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Which haply by much company might be urged:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And so say I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then be it so; and go we to determine

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, and you, my mother, will you go

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To give your censures in this weighty business?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: With all our harts.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM and GLOUCESTER

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For God's sake, let not us two be behind;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For, by the way, I'll sort occasion,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As index to the story we late talk'd of,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My other self, my counsel's consistory,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I, like a child, will go by thy direction.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt
